Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Each event contains attributes such as timestamp, activity, department, patient information (age and gender), and other details. By analyzing these, I aim to identify patterns suggesting which activities belong to the same patient journey.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Since patient journeys are often sequential in nature, I assume that events with shared attributes like patient_age, patient_gender, and department likely belong to the same case, unless another case starts for the same attributes.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Events in healthcare workflows typically follow a logical sequence, such as Register Patient -> Triage -> Diagnosis -> Treatment -> Discharge. This understanding helps me group sequential events that fit such patterns into the same case.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: I checked whether inferred groupings align with healthcare workflows by ordering events chronologically and analyzing overlaps. For example, if activities like 'Triage' and 'Doctor Consultation' reference the same patient and department, they are part of the same case.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: I re-evaluated initial assumptions when groupings became excessive (e.g., treating each event as a standalone case resulted in an implausibly high number of cases). This prompted a return to my inductive reasoning.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: I applied a heuristic: group events by unique combinations of patient_age, patient_gender, and department to minimize overly granular conclusions while maintaining logical consistency.
